column4: after i type sudo apt-get install tftpd, in what mode i start it?
what mode are you reffering to? AFAIR tftpd is started from (x)inetd
by default
i want to start tftpd server on my local machine but i don't know how

tftpd is started by inetd or xinetd by default. you might want to edit /etc/hosts.allow to allow connections to your tftpd port. if you don't have inetd or xinetd (which is higly unlikely) yo might want to run tftpd in daemon mode. read man tftpd (or man in.tftpd ?)
yep, but /etc/init.d/tftpd-hpa don't answer me
why do you want to have tftp anyway?
'cause i want to upgrade my router firmware
and you want to install a tftp *server* on your box?
yes, 'cause i want to transfer the firmware from my box to my router
you might want to look at atftp, it is a tftp *client*. Though I can't be sure, your router should have a tftp *server* running
my router got a tftp, i want to know only in what mode i start tftpd on my box
oops it seems that atftp is a server as well, but I think you need a client
i got a client too
then I can't help you since I don't understand your question
try connecting to the router with a client
if you are sure that you need a tftp server I can't help you with tftpd-hpa since I never used it. If you install tftpd it is set up to be run by (x)inetd. You just would have to configure it a bit

the problem is very simple, i want to upgrade the firmware of my router, so i donwload on my box a latest firmware, and now i want to move this firmware in my router by tftp, but i don't know in what mode i start tftpd lol
it is very likely that tftpd-hpa is also run by inetd
what is this mode you are reffering to?
what I am saying is that most propably you don't need the tftp*d*, you just need a tftp client to connect to your router
yep, but tell me how i start tftpd ?
in.tftpd -l
